title: A little help crediting designers accurately, please...
content:
For the end credits of my new movie, I need to know who the designer of ITC Franklin Gothic Extra Condensed is. MyFonts names Morris Fuller Benton first but also credits David Berlow and Victor Caruso. Was either of the latter individually responsible for the EC font, or was that part of the original Benton design?

 [‹ (x) Renda-se](http://web.archive.org/web/20071010134803/http:/typophile.com/node/5632 "Go to previous forum topic") [(x) Target "Save from top" - Cocktail Shaker {Chesh} ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20071010134803/http:/typophile.com/node/5628 "Go to next forum topic")
author: cheshiredave

comments.content:
I seem to remember that the Extra Condenseds were designed   
by Berlow solo, but it's too long ago and I haven't got anything   
to double-check my recollections with. ![:-(](http://web.archive.org/web/20071010134803im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/clipart/sad.gif)

Thanks, Yves,   
   
One more -- anyone know who designed Gothic 821?

Tricky: [Gothic 821](http://web.archive.org/web/20071010134803/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/bitstream/gothic-821/) is in fact Bitstream's version of Berthold's   
 [Block Extra Condensed](http://web.archive.org/web/20071010134803/http:/www.philsfonts.com/detail.html?sku=BQ90004005P1) (I hope I don't get sued for revealing   
this ![:-)](http://web.archive.org/web/20071010134803im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/clipart/happy.gif)) which was originally designed by H. Hoffmann   
somewhere between 1908 and 1927. So I guess "Bitstream   
design department" might do if you want to avoid litigation. ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20071010134803im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/clipart/bigsmile.gif)
Oh, great -- I stumbled into the Great Litigation Problem.
Hehe, found [this](http://web.archive.org/web/20071010134803/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/83/11978.html?1056141396) when Googling. Scroll to the bottom.
Did Hoffmann do the condensed version, or is that a Spiekermann design? Guess I could ask him, but wow, what a minefield I'd be walking into.

Well, the 1908-1927 makes me believe Hoffmann did all   
the versions, as I'd find it highly unlikely he'd have spent   
19 years designing say the basic non-condensed weights.

But don't mention Spiekermann, he did the Berthold digitization!   
   
Wait, who's that behind your back, breathing down your neck?!   
   
Oh no, it's the Berthold

He might have just been being lazy, though.   
   
Thanks, Yves -- you're now credited under Typographic Research! Care to proofread the credits?

\> Wait, who's that behind your back, breathing down your neck?!   
   
Ja!

To use one of my all-time favourite Spiekermann quotes:   
"Ve hav vays for making you talk..." ![:-)](http://web.archive.org/web/20071010134803im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/clipart/happy.gif)
